Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Synthesis of Isomeric Carbolines by Tandem Palladium Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry Division supports the research of Professor Seann Mulcahy in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Providence College. Professor Mulcahy and his undergraduate students are developing a new methodology for the synthesis of a class of organic compounds called isomeric carbolines. These molecules are known to have attractive biological properties, which range from neurochemical effects to antibacterial and anticancer activity. One major goal of this project is to use compounds containing the element, palladium, as a catalyst that will stitch together these molecules in a single vessel from simpler precursors. Such an efficient chemical process would reduce the time, energy, and resources needed for the synthesis of carbolines. The project further is serving as a training tool for undergraduate students at Providence College, including those students from disadvantaged backgrounds. The project's breadth reaches beyond the research laboratory and is being incorporated into the undergraduate curriculum, a summer bridge program, and outreach activities in Providence public schools. All of the students involved in this work are gaining problem solving and critical thinking skills that are needed for success in chemistry at all levels.

This project involves the development of catalytic, one-pot procedures for the synthesis of isomeric alpha, beta, gamma and delta-carboline heterocycles that have important biochemical function including neuropharmacological activity. Specific targets of this research have potential as molecular probes for studying diseases of the brain. The overarching strategy in this work is the use of a single palladium precursor that will catalyze two mechanistically unique transformations. The first objective is to complete the synthesis of beta-carbolines which have an additional ring attached. By performing a tandem Sonogashira/[2+2+2] cyclization in the same flask, these molecules are created in an atom-economical way using a "multitasking" palladium catalyst. The second objective is to devise similar strategies for the more electron-rich alpha-carboline isomers. The final scientific objective is to synthesize precursor alkynylnitrile and functionalized iodoaniline molecules leading to the gamma- and delta-isomers. The substrate scope, catalytic efficiency, and ligand/solvent effects are optimized for each isomeric class. Equally important in this work is the training of undergraduate students to become better scientists. Through their involvement in original research, undergraduates explore new areas of chemical synthesis and catalysis. The project also seeks to recruit underrepresented groups to study chemistry, both through a "summer bridge" research experience for incoming students or the Catalysts for Chemistry outreach program in Providence public schools.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded project in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Providence College (PC) developed new methods for the preparation of molecules known as carbolines. These molecules exist in many forms, and we took particular interest in the α- and β-isomers due to their importance as substructures in bioactive molecules. We designed a strategy that used transition metal catalysts to rapidly construct a diverse set of these molecules from simpler starting materials. Our work has shown that both rhodium and palladium may be used in the construction of these molecules. When using rhodium, we were able to construct both sets of molecules incredibly efficiently using a linear sequence. When using palladium, we learned that we could synthesize the same molecules in fewer steps because palladium could catalyze multiple bond-forming events in the same reaction flask. This has the effect of reducing waste generation in the synthesis of these complex molecules. Our two strategies to access these α- and β-carbolines are robust in the sense that our method can tolerate small changes to the periphery of the molecules, which make them attractive to others who may want to use our strategies to make new compounds. These molecules could also be used as probes in medicine and biology, so establishing a robust synthesis will accelerate bioactivity studies in the future. We have published two articles: one with six undergraduate coauthors in the scientific journal Tetrahedron Letters, and a second article with five different undergraduate coauthors in the journal Organic Letters. This research has also been presented at several American Chemical Society National Meetings during the award period.

While funds from NSF for this project have been used to make substantial progress in developing new chemical reactions, the award has other impacts that are no less important, including the training and mentoring of undergraduate students in the chemical sciences. The award has funded the summer stipends of six undergraduate students, including underrepresented minorities and women. Other students have also made valuable contributions to this project during the academic year for credit. A total of ten students have been impacted by this award, 60% of whom come from underrepresented groups. Students who have graduated with their baccalaureate degree are either in the workforce or have enrolled in graduate or professional studies. In addition, our research has been integrated into the advanced laboratory curriculum with the implementation of a new experiment known as a Sonogashira coupling. Scientific outreach activities to the public have involved the creation of a sustainable catalysis experiment for adoption in high school chemistry courses at two local high schools, one for women and one that enrolls a high proportion of underrepresented students. Finally, this project has been critical for the career trajectory of the principal investigator, who is now a tenured associate professor in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. It has also had a multiplier effect on the scientific infrastructure at PC. This is no better demonstrated than a National Science Foundation Major Research Instrumentation award to the principal investigator for the acquisition of a new nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer that was installed in June 2020.


Last Modified: 11/13/2020
Modified by: Seann Mulcahy
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This NSF-funded project in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Providence College (PC) developed new methods for the preparation of molecules known as carbolines. These molecules exist in many forms, and we took particular interest in the α- and β-isomers due to their importance as substructures in bioactive molecules. When using rhodium, we were able to construct both sets of molecules incredibly efficiently using a linear sequence. When using palladium, we learned that we could synthesize the same molecules in fewer steps because palladium could catalyze multiple bond-forming events in the same reaction flask. This has the effect of reducing waste generation in the synthesis of these complex molecules. Our two strategies to access these α- and β-carbolines are robust in the sense that our method can tolerate small changes to the periphery of the molecules, which make them attractive to others who may want to use our strategies to make new compounds. These molecules could also be used as probes in medicine and biology, so establishing a robust synthesis will accelerate bioactivity studies in the future. We have published two articles: one with six undergraduate coauthors in the scientific journal Tetrahedron Letters, and a second article with five different undergraduate coauthors in the journal Organic Letters. While funds from NSF for this project have been used to make substantial progress in developing new chemical reactions, the award has other impacts that are no less important, including the training and mentoring of undergraduate students in the chemical sciences. The award has funded the summer stipends of six undergraduate students, including underrepresented minorities and women. Other students have also made valuable contributions to this project during the academic year for credit. A total of ten students have been impacted by this award, 60% of whom come from underrepresented groups. Students who have graduated with their baccalaureate degree are either in the workforce or have enrolled in graduate or professional studies. In addition, our research has been integrated into the advanced laboratory curriculum with the implementation of a new experiment known as a Sonogashira coupling. Finally, this project has been critical for the career trajectory of the principal investigator, who is now a tenured associate professor in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry.
